Facile fabrication of atomically dispersed Pt catalysts on MgFe2O4 toward efficient CO oxidation Fen Wang Writing – review & editing Writing – original draft Validation Funding acquisition Supervision a b ⁎ Yulong Li Validation Methodology Investigation Data curation a Yao Ouyang Validation Methodology Data curation a Xiumiao Yang Writing – review & editing Validation Investigation Data curation c ⁎ a School of Chemical and Blasting Engineering, Anhui University of Science and Technology, Huainan 232001, China School of Chemical and Blasting Engineering Anhui University of Science and Technology Huainan 232001 China aSchool of Chemical and Blasting Engineering, Anhui University of Science and Technology, Huainan 232001, China b Institute of Environment-friendly Materials and Occupational Health of Anhui University of Science and Technology (Wuhu), Wuhu 241003, China Institute of Environment-friendly Materials and Occupational Health of Anhui University of Science and Technology (Wuhu) Wuhu 241003 China bInstitute of Environment-friendly Materials and Occupational Health of Anhui University of Science and Technology (Wuhu), Wuhu 241003, China c School of Mechanical Engineering, Southeast University, Nanjing 211189, China School of Mechanical Engineering Southeast University Nanjing 211189 China cSchool of Mechanical Engineering, Southeast University, Nanjing 211189, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Catalytic oxidation is an efficient way for removing low-concentration of toxic CO. The noble metal catalysts demonstrate outstanding catalytic properties in CO oxidation, but their high-cost present great challenges for further applications. Thus, developing atomically dispersed noble metal on support is a promising candidate because of the highest atom utilization efficiency. In this paper, a range of MgFe2O4 supported atomically dispersed Pt catalysts with different Pt loading (1–5 wt.%) have been successfully developed by simple incipient wetness impregnation technique. The activity of Pt/MgFe2O4 increases with Pt loading for CO oxidation. The catalytic activity of the 5Pt/MgFe2O4 (T50 = 102 °C, T90 = 133 °C) is much better than that of the 5Pt/Fe2O3 (T50 = 132 °C, T90 = 146 °C) and commonly used 5Pt/Al2O3 with PtOx size of ∼1.6 nm (T50 = 156 °C, T90 = 163 °C) at WHSV of 30,000 mL h−1 gcat. −1. All Pt/MgFe2O4 catalysts displayed superior cyclic stability throughout five consecutive heating–cooling cycles via a possible reaction mechanism of Mars–van Krevelen. The 1Pt/MgFe2O4 and 3Pt/MgFe2O4 were gradually deactivated in the long-term catalytic stability testing of 150 °C, and the activity could be fully restored after regeneration, suggesting that the catalysts deactivation was due to the formation of carbonates. These above results provide a useful reference for the development of advanced CO oxidation catalysts in the future. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Platinum MgFe2O4 Atomically dispersed catalysts Carbonates CO oxidation Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Carbon monoxide (CO) gas is widely generated from incomplete combustion of carbon-containing compounds. CO is highly toxic. It binds with hemoglobin in blood, which leads to a decrease in the supply of oxygen, thus causing damages for the central nervous system [1]. Even small amounts of CO can cause serious poison on human body in enclosed environments. In addition, even very low concentrations of CO can poison the metal catalysts of important industrial reactions. For example, even trace of CO (ppm-level) in the H2 feed can result in a drastic drop in electrocatalytic activity of anode Pt catalysts in fuel cell [2]. For ammonia synthesis, CO is a poison of the Fe-based catalysts [3]. Catalytic oxidation has been currently considered as one of the most effective techniques of removing CO. The main challenge of this techniques lies in designing low-cost and highly efficient CO oxidation catalysts. Although transition metal oxides catalysts, such as CuO [4,5], Co3O4 [6,7], and MnO2 [8,9] have the advantages of low cost, their CO oxidation activity is far below than that of the noble metal (like Pt, Au, Pd, Ru and Rh) catalysts [10–12]. Among them, Pt catalysts are the most used for oxidation reactions. In order to maximize the utilization of each platinum atom and reduce the cost of catalysts, the atomically dispersed Pt catalysts have attracted much attention since 2011 [13]. The atomically dispersed Pt catalysts are widely used in water–gas shift reaction [14,15], CO oxidation reaction [16], and so on. Recently, iron oxide (FeOx) has been reported as an excellent support in dispersing noble metals Pt [13], Ir [17], and Au [18] through the strong metal–support interaction. However, FeOx as a monometallic oxide has relatively low surface area, especially after the heat treatment at high temperature. Spinel materials, especially mixed oxides, have been intensively investigated and presented promising surface area and thermal stability as catalyst support materials for supported catalysts. On the basis of the above considerations, the use of MgFe2O4 as catalyst support to prepare atomically dispersed Pt catalysts with various Pt loadings is very promising. Here, we have successfully synthesized a range of atomically dispersed Pt/MgFe2O4 with various Pt loading by simple incipient wetness impregnation. The performance of Pt/MgFe2O4 in CO oxidation was assessed and the structure of catalysts was explored. The activity of Pt/MgFe2O4 increases with Pt loading and the excellent cyclic stability was achieved on all the Pt/MgFe2O4 catalysts for CO oxidation under WHSV of 30,000 mL h−1 gcat. −1 via a possible mechanism of Mars–van Krevelen. For comparison, the 5Pt/Fe2O3 and commonly used 5Pt/Al2O3 with particle size of ∼1.6 nm was also prepared and the 5Pt/MgFe2O4 is more active than the 5Pt/Fe2O3 and 5Pt/Al2O3. The deactivation behaviour of the 1Pt/MgFe2O4 and 3Pt/MgFe2O4 during the long-term reaction at 150 °C has been studied and we confirm that the carbonates are the main reason for Pt/MgFe2O4 catalyst deactivation. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of Pt/MgFe2O4, Pt/Fe2O3 and Pt/Al2O3 MgFe2O4 was synthesized through a solid-state method which we reported before [19]. Briefly, magnesium sulfate, iron nitrate nonahydrate, sodium chloride and sodium hydroxide with molar ratio of 1: 2: 10: 8 were mixed evenly by grinding vigorously for 30 min. After calcination at 700 °C in ambient air for 1 h, the obtained solid was washed thoroughly with pure water and finally dried at 120 °C. Fe2O3 was prepared using same procedure as MgFe2O4. Iron nitrate nonahydrate, sodium chloride and sodium hydroxide with molar ratio of 1: 5: 3 were used in the preparation of Fe2O3. Al2O3 support was purchased from Shandong Aluminum Industry. Pt/MgFe2O4 (with nominal Pt loading of 1, 3 and 5 wt.%) were synthesized through facile incipient wetness impregnation of MgFe2O4 with H2PtCl6·6H2O (Damas-beta, Shanghai, China) aqueous solution. The resulting sample was dried at 60 °C, followed by calcination at 500 °C in ambient air for 5 h. After natural cooling, the acquired solid was washed thoroughly with pure water and then dried at 120 °C. For comparison, Pt/Fe2O3 and Pt/Al2O3 (with nominal Pt loading of 5 wt.%) were also synthesized using same procedure as Pt/MgFe2O4 catalysts. The produced catalysts were denoted as xPt/MgFe2O4, xPt/Fe2O3, and xPt/Al2O3, where x represents the nominal Pt loading of the catalysts. 2.2 Catalyst structural characterization BET surface areas of samples were determined on a Micromeritics ASAP 2460 analyzers by using nitrogen physisorption at −196 °C. The samples were treated at 200 °C in a vacuum for 3 h prior to measurements. The Pt weight content of as-prepared samples was obtained by inductively coupled plasma spectrometer using an Agilent 5110 apparatus. The crystal structure of samples was characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD) on a SmartLab SE apparatus. The morphology and elemental distribution of as-prepared samples were investigated by aberration-corrected scanning-transmission electron-microscopy (AC-STEM) on a FEI Themis Z instrument with a Super X-EDX detector. Diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTs) data was collected from a Bruker Tensor 27 instruments. Before the infrared tests, the sample was treated at 120 °C in Ar for 30 min for removing impurities and water. After cooling down to 30 °C under a stream of Ar gas, 20 vol.% CO/Ar was introduced to reach saturated CO adsorption. Subsequently, the gas was switched to Ar gas for purging and the DRIFT spectra were acquired. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) signals were recorded on an ESCALAB 250Xi instrument. The values of binding energies were calibrated by C 1s located at 284.6 eV. Hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) experiments were conducted using an AutoChem II 2920 instrument. Before reduction, the samples were exposed to Ar of 300 °C for 30 min and then cooled down to 50 °C. Subsequently, the temperature of samples was increased to 900 °C in 10 vol.% H2/Ar at 10 °C/min. CO temperature-programmed desorption (CO-TPD) experiments were conducted on a Bel Cata II Chemisorption analyzer which coupled with a mass spectrometer. Before CO absorption, the samples were exposed to He of 300 °C for 1 h and then cooled down to 50 °C. Subsequently, 10 vol.% CO/He of 50 mL/min was pass through the sample for 1 h. Then, the gas was switched to He for removal of the weakly adsorbed CO. Finally, the temperature of samples was ramped to 900 °C and the mass spectrometric (MS) signals of CO with an m/z of 28 and CO2 with an m/z of 44 were recorded in the heating process. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) characterization was conducted using a Nicolet iS50 instrument. Before measurements, the sample was finely dispersed in KBr and then compressed into a slice. 2.3 Catalytic performance tests The activity and stability of Pt/MgFe2O4, Pt/Fe2O3 and Pt/Al2O3 were tested for CO oxidation in fixed-bed apparatus of atmospheric pressure. A mixture of 50 mg of powdered catalyst and 1 g of silica sand was introduced into a quartz tube with internal diameters of 10 mm. The reactant including 1 vol.% CO, 1 vol.% O2 and 98 vol.% N2 was fed into catalyst bed. The activity test was conducted in the range of room temperature to 300 °C at 25 mL/min and the weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) was 30,000 mL h−1 gcat. −1. Catalysts durability tests were performed at 150 °C under WHSV of 30,000 or 50,500 mL h−1 gcat. −1. Repeated reaction-regeneration cycles were performed as follows. The steady state test was proceeded at 150 °C for 3 h with WHSV of 50,500 mL h−1 gcat. −1. The regeneration process was conducted at 200 °C in 25 mL/min of 20 vol.% O2/N2 for 30 min. Component of the outlet gas was determined using an on-line infrared analyzer (FGA 10). The calculated formula of CO conversion was (CCO, inlet − CCO, outlet)/CCO, inlet × 100 %, in which CCO, inlet and CCO, outlet represented the CO concentrations of gas mixtures at inlet and outlet, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance The catalytic activities of Pt/MgFe2O4, Pt/Fe2O3 and Pt/Al2O3 in CO oxidation were assessed. The results are displayed in Fig. 1 a. The catalyst activities were assessed by the values of T10, T50 and T90, which correspond to the temperature at which CO conversion reaches 10 %, 50 % and 90 %, respectively. It was observed that the MgFe2O4 exhibited inferior activity for CO oxidation, giving 183, 231 and 248 °C of T10, T50 and T90 values, respectively. The catalysts exhibit apparently better activities than pure MgFe2O4 with addition of Pt. CO conversion temperature of the Pt/MgFe2O4 catalysts are ranked as follows: 1Pt/MgFe2O4 (T10 = 108 °C, T50 = 148 °C, T90 = 173 °C) < 3Pt/MgFe2O4 (T10 = 80 °C, T50 = 117 °C, T90 = 149 °C) < 5Pt/MgFe2O4 (T10 = 67 °C, T50 = 102 °C, T90 = 133 °C). The findings suggest that Pt species play key roles in catalyst performance for CO oxidation. Additionally, the influence of support type was also investigated. 5Pt/Fe2O3 and 5Pt/Al2O3 show much lower activity than 5Pt/MgFe2O4 with similar loading of Pt. The T10, T50 and T90 over 5Pt/Fe2O3 are 84, 132 and 146 °C, respectively. The T10, T50 and T90 over 5Pt/Al2O3 are 127, 156 and 163 °C, respectively, while are 67, 102 and 133 °C for 5Pt/MgFe2O4. Compared with Fe2O3 and Al2O3 supports, the MgFe2O4 significantly enhances the Pt catalyst activity in CO oxidation. The corresponding T10, T50 and T90 values over Pt/MgFe2O4, Pt/Fe2O3 and Pt/Al2O3 are presented in Table S1. Fig. 1b shows the Arrhenius plots for CO oxidation on Pt/MgFe2O4, Pt/Fe2O3 and Pt/Al2O3 at low CO conversions (below 20 %). Table 1 presents the values of apparent activation energy (Ea) over Pt/MgFe2O4, Pt/Fe2O3 and Pt/Al2O3, which were calculated from the slopes of Arrhenius plots. The 1Pt/MgFe2O4, 3Pt/MgFe2O4, 5Pt/MgFe2O4, 5Pt/Fe2O3 and 5Pt/Al2O3 presented the Ea values of 49.8, 43.9, 39.8, 53.5 and 102.0 kJ/mol, respectively. For Pt/MgFe2O4 catalysts, the Ea values decrease with increasing the Pt loading, and all these Ea values are lower than that of 5Pt/Fe2O3 and 5Pt/Al2O3. Such low Ea values on the Pt/MgFe2O4 are favorable for catalysts to exhibit high performance in CO oxidation reaction. The CO turnover rates at 80 °C on 1Pt/MgFe2O4, 3Pt/MgFe2O4 and 5Pt/MgFe2O4 are calculated to be 0.0020, 0.0025 and 0.0028 mol/(molPt-s), respectively, showing a slight increase with the increase of Pt loading in Pt/MgFe2O4. The durability and cyclic stability of the Pt/MgFe2O4 catalyst were investigated under WHSV of 30,000 mL h−1 gcat. −1. As illustrated in Fig. 2 a, the 5Pt/MgFe2O4 shows stable CO conversion of 100 % during the TOS of 23 h. The 3Pt/MgFe2O4 catalyst exhibits initial CO conversion of 90.9 %, and then deactivates gradually during 12 h TOS with CO conversion decreasing to 69.1 %. The 1Pt/MgFe2O4 catalyst exhibits initial CO conversion of 54.1 %, and then gradually deactivates at about 12 h TOS with CO conversion declining to 18.9 %. As displayed in Fig. 2b–d, the five conversion curves over 1Pt/MgFe2O4 are almost same for the five consecutive catalytic reaction cycles. Similar phenomena can be observed on 3Pt/MgFe2O4 and 5Pt/MgFe2O4 catalysts. These results indicated that the Pt/MgFe2O4 catalysts exhibited excellent cyclic stability in CO oxidation rection. The regeneration stability of the 1Pt/MgFe2O4 and 3Pt/MgFe2O4 catalysts was investigated with interval regeneration for every 3 h. High WHSV of 50,500 mL h−1 gcat. −1 was adopted in order to deactivate the catalyst quickly. As illustrated in Fig. 3 a, 1Pt/MgFe2O4 displayed a continuous decrease in the CO conversion in the first reaction period from 32.7 % to 13.9 %. In the subsequent second and third runs, the initial CO conversion can be recovered to 36.6 %, and then decreased to 9.9 % and 7.9 % within 3 h, respectively. As shown in Fig. 3b, in the first reaction period, the 3Pt/MgFe2O4 catalysts exhibited initial CO conversion of 83.2 % and then deactivates gradually during 3 h TOS with CO conversion decreasing to 76.2 %. In the subsequent second and third runs, the initial CO conversion can be recovered to 100 %, and then decreased to 65.3 % and 91.1 % within 3 h, respectively. These results demonstrate that the accumulation of carbonates is the major reason of deactivation for Pt/MgFe2O4 catalysts, which is consistent with literature reports that Pt-CoO/Al2O3 deactivation in CO oxidation is cause by the formation of carbonate covering the active sites [20]. 3.2 Catalyst characterizations The actual Pt loadings of Pt/MgFe2O4, Pt/Fe2O3 and Pt/Al2O3 catalysts analysed by ICP-OES are illustrated in Table 1. The Pt loadings are 1.0, 2.9, 4.9, 5.2 and 5.1 wt.% for 1Pt/MgFe2O4, 3Pt/MgFe2O4, 5Pt/MgFe2O4, 5Pt/Fe2O3 and 5Pt/Al2O3, respectively, which is close to the nominal values. It indicates that the Pt loadings are almost precisely controlled during the preparation process. Fig. 4 presents the adsorption isotherms of N2 and the pore-size distributions curves for Pt/MgFe2O4, 5Pt/Fe2O3 and Pt/Al2O3 catalysts. The 1Pt/MgFe2O4, 3Pt/MgFe2O4 and 5Pt/MgFe2O4 catalysts exhibit similar BET surface areas of 93.2, 92.1 and 91.7 m2/g, respectively. The 5Pt/Fe2O3 has surface areas of 13.8 m2/g, while the 5Pt/Al2O3 catalyst has surface areas as high as 203.6 m2/g, as illustrated in Table 1. It is obvious that the Pt/MgFe2O4, 5Pt/Fe2O3 and Pt/Al2O3 catalysts have mesoporous structure and the pore sizes are 10.0, 10.9, 9.0, 17.7 and 6.0 nm for 1Pt/MgFe2O4, 3Pt/MgFe2O4, 5Pt/MgFe2O4, 5Pt/Fe2O3 and 5Pt/Al2O3, respectively. The corresponding pore volumes are 0.28, 0.28, 0.23, 0.06 and 0.37 cm3/g. Fig. 5 displays the XRD patterns of Pt/MgFe2O4, Pt/Fe2O3 and Pt/Al2O3 catalysts. The 5Pt/Fe2O3 exhibits obvious diffractions indexed to Fe2O3 (JCPDS 33–0664) and Pt (JCPDS 04–0802), respectively. The average crystalline sizes of Pt were calculated to be above 100 nm by using Scherrer equation based on the XRD diffraction at 2θ of 39.8°. The Pt/MgFe2O4 and Pt/Al2O3 exhibit broad diffractions indexed to spinel MgFe2O4 (JCPDS 73–1720) and Al2O3 (JCPDS 10–0425), respectively. No detectable diffraction corresponding to PtOx was observed due to its small particle size below XRD detection limit, indicating that highly dispersed Pt oxidic species exist in both Pt/MgFe2O4 and Pt/Al2O3 catalysts. This result was further verified by ACHAADF-STEM characterization. Representative ACHAADF-STEM images of 1Pt/MgFe2O4, 3Pt/MgFe2O4 and 5Pt/MgFe2O4 are displayed in Figs. 6 a, b and c, respectively. For 1Pt/MgFe2O4, 3Pt/MgFe2O4 and 5Pt/MgFe2O4 catalysts, the isolated single Pt atoms were observed on MgFe2O4 surfaces from high-magnification images. In addition, very few Pt dimers and clusters are observed in the 3Pt/MgFe2O4 and 5Pt/MgFe2O4 catalysts, as indicated by green and yellow circles in the images, respectively. As shown in Figs. S1a–c, no PtOx nanoparticles can be observed on the 1Pt/MgFe2O4, 3Pt/MgFe2O4 and 5Pt/MgFe2O4 catalysts from the low-magnification images. By analyzing many images of different magnification of the 1Pt/MgFe2O4, 3Pt/MgFe2O4 and 5Pt/MgFe2O4 catalysts, we have found that only atomically dispersed Pt atoms exist in the catalysts without the presence of PtOx nanoparticles. Fig. S2 displays the EDS images of the 5Pt/MgFe2O4 catalyst. It demonstrates that the Pt atoms distribute evenly on MgFe2O4. Fig. 6d presents the STEM images and the corresponding particle size distribution results of 5Pt/Al2O3 catalyst. It is obvious that a large number of nanosized PtOx particles are densely and evenly supported on Al2O3. As displayed in the insert images in Fig. 6d, the statistical size distribution illustrates that the sizes of the PtOx particles are mainly in a narrow range of 1.0–2.2 nm with average size of ∼ 1.6 nm. Furthermore, as displayed in Fig. S3, the EDS images of the 5Pt/Al2O3 catalyst exhibits the even elemental distributions of Pt, Al, and O, suggesting the uniform deposition of the PtOx nanoparticles on the surface of Al2O3. To further confirm the structure of Pt species in Pt/MgFe2O4 and Pt/Al2O3, in situ CO-DRIFTs tests were performed. As seen from Fig. 7 , all samples show two typical absorption peaks at 2169 and 2119 cm–1, which are related to gaseous CO [21]. For 3Pt/MgFe2O4 and 5Pt/MgFe2O4, a main peak at 2062 and 2087 cm–1, attributed to CO linear adsorption on oxidized monoatomic Pt [22], was observed. In addition, a very weak peak at 1834 cm–1, ascribed to the bridged CO adsorption on two adjacent Pt atoms, was also observed in the 3Pt/MgFe2O4 and 5Pt/MgFe2O4. The formation of bridged CO adsorption indicates the presence of dimers or clusters of Pt [23], which is consistent with the results of STEM. Differently, on 1Pt/MgFe2O4 catalyst, no adsorption of CO was observed, which is consistent with literature reported results that no adsorption of CO was detected on Pt1/MgAl1.2Fe0.8O4 [24]. For 5Pt/Al2O3 catalyst, the CO linear adsorption at 2114 and 2056 cm–1 and bridged adsorption at 1810 cm–1 on small oxidized Pt nanoparticles were observed, respectively [25,26]. To investigate the electronic structures of platinum species in catalysts, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed. Fig. S4 shows the XPS survey spectra for Pt/MgFe2O4, Pt/Fe2O3 and Pt/Al2O3. The results indicate the presence of Pt, Mg, Fe, and O elements in all Pt/MgFe2O4. The elements of Pt, Fe, and O exist in 5Pt/Fe2O3. The elements of Pt, Al, and O were detected in 5Pt/Al2O3. As displayed in Fig. 8 a, the Pt 4f spectra of all Pt/MgFe2O4 catalysts could be deconvoluted into four peaks. The pair of peaks at binding energies of 72.8 and 76.0 eV are assigned to Pt2+ species [27–29], whereas the peaks at binding energies of 74.8 and 78.2 eV are ascribed to Pt4+ species, suggesting the likely co-existence of both Pt4+ and Pt2+ on the Pt/MgFe2O4 surface. For 5Pt/Fe2O3, similar Pt species exist, showing decreases of 0.4 and 0.7 eV in the binding energies of Pt4+ and Pt2+, respectively. Although the Pt 4f signals are the most intense for Pt species, Pt 4d spectra were recorded for 5Pt/Al2O3 catalyst because of the overlap of the Pt 4f signal with Al 2p. Fig. 8b presents Pt 4d spectra of 5Pt/Al2O3 catalyst. For Pt 4d spectra, it can be fitted into four peaks with BEs of 314.9, 317.6, 331.9 and 334.6 eV. The pairs of binding energies centred at 314.9 and 331.9 eV, and 317.6 and 334.6 eV are assigned to Pt2+ and Pt4+ species, respectively [30,31], indicating that the existence of Pt2+ and Pt4+ species for 5Pt/Al2O3. According to the ratio of peak area of Pt2+ to the sum of peak areas of Pt2+ and Pt4+, the proportion of Pt2+ in 5Pt/MgFe2O4 and 5Pt/Al2O3 is calculated to be 36.8 % and 29.3 %, respectively. It is generally believed that the Pt2+ species in CO oxidation is more active than Pt4+ species at low temperature [32,33], indicating that the activity of 5Pt/MgFe2O4 in CO oxidation may be higher than that of 5Pt/Al2O3. Fig. S5 shows the O 1s XPS spectra for Pt/MgFe2O4, Pt/Fe2O3 and Pt/Al2O3. The fitted peak at 531.0 eV in Pt/MgFe2O4 is attributed to the adsorbed oxygen species on the catalyst surface [19]. Compared with Pt/MgFe2O4, the binding energies of the adsorbed oxygen species on 5Pt/Fe2O3 and 5Pt/Al2O3 have increased by 0.6 and 0.8 eV, respectively, suggesting the more active adsorbed oxygen species formed on Pt/MgFe2O4 catalyst [13,34]. It was reported that the adsorbed oxygen species could promote the adsorption and activation of O2 molecules [19]. The more active adsorbed oxygen species in Pt/MgFe2O4 are beneficial for its high catalytic activity. Fig. 9 a shows the H2-TPR results of Pt/MgFe2O4, Pt/Fe2O3, Pt/Al2O3 and MgFe2O4 support. A distinct H2 consumption peak centred at 120 °C was observed for 1Pt/MgFe2O4, which is ascribed to the reduction of oxidized Pt species [29]. However, the reduction temperature of oxidized Pt decreased with increasing Pt loading (106 °C for 3Pt/MgFe2O4 and 97 °C for 5Pt/MgFe2O4), suggesting that the metal–support interaction became weaker. Considering the fact that Mg2+ is rather difficult to be reduced, the reduction peak above 240 °C in MgFe2O4 and Pt/MgFe2O4 is associated with Fe species reduction [25]. For 5Pt/Fe2O3, there is a distinct reduction peak at 364 °C, which is attributed to the reduction of oxidized Pt species. Reduction peaks above 400 °C are ascribed to the reduction of Fe species [35]. As for the 5Pt/Al2O3, only a broad and relatively weak reduction peak at 196 °C was observed in the range of 50−900 °C, which is ascribed to the facts that small size of oxidized Pt nanoparticles (∼2 nm) can be reduced below 50 °C [36]. This difference of reduction temperature for oxidized Pt suggests that the bonding of oxygen species in Pt/MgFe2O4 and Pt/Fe2O3 is stronger compared to that of Pt/Al2O3. Fig. 9b shows the CO-TPD results of the Pt/MgFe2O4 catalysts. Significant quantities of CO2 and minor amounts of CO were detected for all Pt/MgFe2O4 catalysts. The production of CO2 is result of the reaction of adsorbed CO species with the lattice oxygen. This is generally seen as the first step of oxidation reaction for Mars–van Krevelen mechanism [37], suggesting that CO oxidation may follow Mars–van Krevelen mechanism on Pt/MgFe2O4 catalysts. The amount of CO2 and CO was calculated from the calibrated desorption peak areas. The total amount of the detected CO2 and CO is 0.08, 0.13 and 0.15 mmol/g for the 1Pt/MgFe2O4, 3Pt/MgFe2O4 and 5Pt/MgFe2O4, respectively, as displayed in Table 1. The amount of adsorbed CO increases in the order of 1Pt/MgFe2O4<3Pt/MgFe2O4<5Pt/MgFe2O4 because CO2 is produced from CO, which is consistent well with the DRIFT data. The FT-IR analyses of the spent 3Pt/MgFe2O4 catalyst after 100 h reaction at 150 °C were performed because no IR signals related to carbonates could be detected over the spent 3Pt/MgFe2O4 after 12 h reaction at 150 °C probably due to the low concentration of carbonates. The obtained FT-IR curves are shown in Fig. 10 . The double band at 1384 and 1352 cm−1 is attributed to the ν3 band splitting of CO3 2− [38]. The band at 2900−3700 cm−1 and 1593 cm−1 are ascribed to the stretching vibrations of O–H and bending vibrations of H–O–H of adsorbed water, respectively [39], whereas the water mainly originated from residual water in KBr. The results indicate that carbonate species produced on 3Pt/MgFe2O4 during the long-term reaction process at 150 °C. 3.3 Discussion An atomically dispersed Pt with Pt loading of 1, 3 and 5 wt.% can be successfully obtained on a MgFe2O4 support. The activity and long-term stability of Pt/MgFe2O4 increased as increasing Pt loading (Figs. 1 and 2a). The obtained 5Pt/MgFe2O4 catalyst showed a high CO oxidation activity (T90 = 133 °C), which surpass the activity of 5Pt/Fe2O3 (T90 = 146 °C) and 5Pt/Al2O3 (T90 = 163 °C) (Table S1). A stable CO conversion of 100 % was obtained during 23 h TOS at 150 °C under WHSV of 30,000 mL h−1 gcat. −1 in 5Pt/MgFe2O4 (Fig. 2a). It was also observed that the Pt/MgFe2O4 with Pt loading of 1, 3 and 5 wt.% has good catalytic cyclic stability for CO oxidation (Figs. 2b–d). The fact that the deactivated 1Pt/MgFe2O4 and 3Pt/MgFe2O4 catalysts can be regenerated after 20 vol.% O2/N2 treatment implies that its deactivation is most probably due to the deposited carbonates (Fig. 3). As seen from XRD data (Fig. 5), the Pt/MgFe2O4 displayed MgFe2O4 phase and the crystalline sizes of Pt in 5Pt/Fe2O3 exceed 100 nm calculated from the peak at 2θ of 39.8°. The AC-STEM and DRIFT results demonstrated that the atomically dispersed Pt species exist in Pt/MgFe2O4 and the PtOx nanoparticles of ∼1.6 nm formed in 5Pt/Al2O3 (Figs. 6 and 7). According to the XPS characterization results, the Pt4+ and Pt2+ species coexist in Pt/MgFe2O4, Pt/Fe2O3 and Pt/Al2O3, and Pt4+ is the main species. Compared with 5Pt/Fe2O3 and 5Pt/Al2O3, the adsorbed oxygen species is more active on Pt/MgFe2O4. H2-TPR results disclosed that the interaction between Pt species and MgFe2O4 decreased with increasing Pt loading (Fig. 9a). CO-TPD results demonstrated that the oxidation of CO on Pt/MgFe2O4 may follow Mars–van Krevelen (MvK) mechanism (Fig. 9b). The deposition of carbonates in the spent 3Pt/MgFe2O4 was further confirmed by FT-IR analysis (Fig. 10). All the above results suggest that the atomically dispersed Pt/MgFe2O4 with Pt loading of 1, 3 and 5 wt.% can be successfully prepared by simple incipient wetness impregnation method and exhibits excellent cyclic stability in CO oxidation reaction. The atomically dispersed 5Pt/MgFe2O4 catalyst indeed is more active than that of the 5Pt/Fe2O3 and commonly used 5Pt/Al2O3 with PtOx size of ∼1.6 nm for CO oxidation. The CO oxidation reaction most probably proceeds via a Mars–van Krevelen (MvK) mechanism over Pt/MgFe2O4 and the deposited carbonates are main reason for deactivating 1Pt/MgFe2O4 and 3Pt/MgFe2O4 in long-term reaction at 150 °C. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, we have reported a facile method for preparing atomically dispersed Pt/MgFe2O4 catalyst with Pt loading of 1, 3 and 5 wt.%. The catalytic test results showed that the activity of Pt/MgFe2O4 increases with increasing Pt loading from 1 to 5 wt.%. All the Pt/MgFe2O4 catalysts display an excellent cyclic stability at WHSV of 30,000 mL h−1 gcat. −1 for CO oxidation, which possibly proceeds via the Mars–van Krevelen reaction mechanism. The atomically dispersed 5Pt/MgFe2O4 displays better catalytic activity than that of the 5Pt/Fe2O3 and commonly used 5Pt/Al2O3 (dPtOx ≈ 1.6 nm). Although an obvious deactivation was observed over 1Pt/MgFe2O4 and 3Pt/MgFe2O4 during the long-term stability test at 150 °C, the activity could be recovered after regeneration at 200 °C due to deactivation caused by carbonates. These findings provide valuable information on design of atomically dispersed Pt-based catalysts with higher efficiency and stability for CO oxidation. coredata.dc:description: Catalytic oxidation is an efficient way for removing low-concentration of toxic CO. The noble metal catalysts demonstrate outstanding catalytic properties in CO oxidation, but their high-cost present great challenges for further applications. Thus, developing atomically dispersed noble metal on support is a promising candidate because of the highest atom utilization efficiency. In this paper, a range of MgFe2O4 supported atomically dispersed Pt catalysts with different Pt loading (1–5 wt.%) have been successfully developed by simple incipient wetness impregnation technique. The activity of Pt/MgFe2O4 increases with Pt loading for CO oxidation. The catalytic activity of the 5Pt/MgFe2O4 (T50 = 102 °C, T90 = 133 °C) is much better than that of the 5Pt/Fe2O3 (T50 = 132 °C, T90 = 146 °C) and commonly used 5Pt/Al2O3 with PtOx size of ∼1.6 nm (T50 = 156 °C, T90 = 163 °C) at WHSV of 30,000 mL h−1 gcat. −1. All Pt/MgFe2O4 catalysts displayed superior cyclic stability throughout five consecutive heating–cooling cycles via a possible reaction mechanism of Mars–van Krevelen. The 1Pt/MgFe2O4 and 3Pt/MgFe2O4 were gradually deactivated in the long-term catalytic stability testing of 150 °C, and the activity could be fully restored after regeneration, suggesting that the catalysts deactivation was due to the formation of carbonates. These above results provide a useful reference for the development of advanced CO oxidation catalysts in the future.
coredata.dc:title: Facile fabrication of atomically dispersed Pt catalysts on MgFe2O4 toward efficient CO oxidation
